comments.body: look into logrotate

linking to troubleshooting theme.  Also, apache includes a tool and the ability to use 'piped logs' for controlling log size/rotation, that could be added to our CC/NC template:

http://httpd.apache.org/docs/1.3/logs.html#piped

-d

We have since an instance where the file was about 2.5GB and it created problems with connections. We had an iptables-repload NAT rule to talk to a SAN, and with the file that big, we couldn't get reliably to the SAN, connections were very unstable, or very hard to establish. After we move away the file, and zero-ed it, the connection was restore perfectly.
At [~dmitrii]'s suggestion, I'm planning to use the same approach for the corresponding NC log.

Just verified that writing ErrorLog via a pipe through Apache's rotatelogs utility will work. This requires changes to the httpd.conf files we provide, as well as tweaks to init scripts (which rewrite the httpd.conf ErrorLog lines).
Out of curiosity, what do folks think is a reasonable rotation size for these logs?

Pros and cons of a couple of techniques:

logrotate:

- Con: Has to SIGHUP httpd to perform rotation.
- Pro: Common, well-understood Linux util.
- Pro: Handles expiring its own rotated logs.

Pipe through rotatelogs (Apache-bundled util):

- Pro: part of Apache.
- Pro: Does not require SIGHUP restart of apache to rotate.
- Con: Does not handle expiring its own rotated logs--an external cron job or similar will be required.
- Con: If run in time-based rotation mode, won't catch files exploding in size.
- Con: If run in size-based rotation mode, will create a new (timestamped) logfile for each httpd restart, regardless of previous logfiles' size.

Ideally, we'd like something that can be set to only rotate based upon size and that won't automatically rotate (and thus re-timestamp a new file) for every httpd restart.

Two questions:

1. [~viglesias] Any idea how long it took that system to run up a 3GB logfile?

2. [~graziano] Was the logfile being written to the SAN?

Absent any objections from interested parties, I'm using Apache's internal rotatelogs utility (which eliminates the need for periodic SIGHUP restarts of httpd) to rotate the cc & nc httpd error logs on a daily basis, and I'm writing a small script utility to expire the rotated logs. (I don't see a reasonable way to combine logrotate & rotatelogs to do this.)
[~juphoff] sorry for the late answer: the file was written on the local disk.
[~awithrow], could you create a doc bug for this as known issue.  [~juphoff], could you provide a reasonable workaround with script as mentioned above?

[~tjcramer] ,

What progress are we making on this ticket? This has hit one of our customers. Do you mind updating the status? Currently the scoping version is 3.3.0 and the label says version 3.3.1 for backend team

Is there an improvement/fix expected in 3.4.0?

[~dmitrii], please take this and prioritize for 3.4
[~chuck], [~kedwards], perhaps this is one for sustaining as well?

[~mspaulding], [~gholms],

I did a lot of research on this one and basically, our solution would be to use logrotate. The final solution is for the following "eucalyptus-[nc/cc]" configuration file to be created under /etc/logrotate.d when the CC/NC service starts and being removed when the service is stopped. An option here would be for the install script to put a single eucalyptus config file for both CC and NC logs and keep it there permanently. Here's and example of the content of the log file

{code}
/var/log/eucalyptus/httpd-cc_error_log {
    size 104857600
    rotate 10
    copytruncate
    nocreate
    nodateext
    nomail
    missingok
}
{code}

The system is running logrotate daily on all configuration files present under /etc/logrotate.d/ which may not be enough for out needs. We also give the option today to our users to modify the eucalyptus.conf configuration file and the NC/CC picks up the log size and rotation size automatically. Another modification I did was to install a script in /etc/cron.hourly that 1) updates the "/etc/logrotate.d/eucalytpus-[cc/nc]" configuration file with new size and rotation counts IF the eucalyptus.conf file has changed in the previous hour and then 2) run logrotate on the eucalyptus files only on an hourly basis. This script is added when service is started and removed when service is stopped.

So basically I need to know the following:
1) Should we have the logrotate config file created/removed based on service status or should the install script install a single configuration file for CC and NC log as below?

{code}
/var/log/eucalyptus/httpd-*_error_log {
    size 104857600
    rotate 10
    copytruncate
    nocreate
    nodateext
    nomail
    missingok
}
{code}

2) Do we need a script installed at service turned up and removed when service is disabled? Or Should is be installed at installation time?

3) Do we need to update the log size and rotation when user modifies eucalyptus.conf? Some agrees that this is following the behavior of our other logs some say we need to let the user decide and modify directly the logrotate config file...

thanks
[~mspaulding], I'm assigning this to you to answer my questions in my previous comment... Assign it back to me when you have answered.

Talked with [~mspaulding] and for now we will have a generic configuration file being dropped under /etc/logrotate.d after make install. The log rotation size and count values will match the defaults from eucalyptus.conf and we will let the user decide on modifying this configuration file themselves. For now we won't run logrotate.d hourly and we'll let the system run its sequence daily...

This one should be resolved in 3.4 and testing branches. This is CC and NC specific. Test case need to validate that a "eucalyptus" configuration file is present in the "/etc/logrotate.d/" directory with the following content:
{noformat}
[root@c-34 eucalyptus]# cat /etc/logrotate.d/eucalyptus 
/opt/eucalyptus/var/log/eucalyptus/httpd-*_error_log {
    size 104857600
    rotate 10
    copytruncate
    nocreate
    nodateext
    nomail
    missingok
}
[root@c-34 eucalyptus]# 
{noformat}
Cron will execute logrotate daily by default and since the file isn't one that grows very fast, this should be plenty. If, for some reason, the httpd logs seems to fill much faster (in orders of Gigs per day), then we should re-evaluate running logrotate much more often.
[~chuck], the Makefile install needs to install the configuration using $DESTDIR/$(etcdir)

Verified the logrotate config is properly installed and is actuating the logs file. And manually ran the command to ensure the log rotation occured:

[root@c-41 ~]# cat /etc/logrotate.d/eucalyptus
//var/log/eucalyptus/httpd-*_error_log {
    size 104857600
    rotate 10
    copytruncate
    nocreate
    nodateext
    nomail
    missingok
}

[root@c-41 ~]# logrotate  /etc/logrotate.conf
[root@c-41 ~]# ll /var/log/eucalyptus/httpd-cc_error_log*
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root         0 Nov 21 00:20 /var/log/eucalyptus/httpd-cc_error_log
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 339840500 Nov 21 00:20 /var/log/eucalyptus/httpd-cc_error_log.1

Note: I had arbitrarily added dated to the log file before running the command (ie 300+MB worth).
